1.content:
It seemed like a normal day. Normal weather, normal news, normal everything. But as Lari sat in her car in the middle of another normal day, in a normal city, she realized that this day was the end of her normal life.

She turned the rearview mirror towards her face and looked at herself. "I have cancer. I have no insurance. I have no money, and no family," she said out loud. "Now what?"

She had just come from the doctor's office, where the doctor had given her the bad news. She was supposed to go back to the doctor tomorrow, but she knew she would not. In her heart, she knew this was something big, lifechanging, and unalterable. Finally, she fixed the mirror in place and started the car. Without looking in the mirror, she entered traffic. A car whizzed by her, honking loudly. Sticking her head out the window, she screamed "Fuck YOU!!!!" An amazing sense of freedom suddenly overtook her, and she drove home without care of who she pissed off.

Her life was just beginning.
1.title: Bad news

choices: Take Kat on a road trip
11.content:
Lari stepped on the gas and gunned it to her best friend's apartment. Traffic was hell, but when you change lanes often, give the finger and scream at people, they get scared and generally stay out of your way. Her best friend, Kat, worked late nights as a bartender in a swanky downtown nightclub. At 2:00 in the afternoon, she was probably sleeping. Lari woke her up with a few carefully thrown pebbles at Kat's window. She was rewarded when Kat's head appeared and she shouted "What the hell is it Lari! I'm sleeping!"

"It's an emergency!"

Kat regarded her for a moment, noted the frantic look on Lari's face, and disappeared from the window. Lari ran around to catch the door buzzer, and met Kat halfway up the stairs. "What is it?" asked Kat. Lari started laughing hysterically, before collapsing in the hallway in tears. Kat had to physically pick Lari up, and help her to the apartment. The story came out in teary bursts. "I've got, brain, in my head, it's cancer, and untreatable, six months at the most, no insurance, and I don't even want to go through chemo anyway!"

"Ok, you're hysterical, Lari, of course you want treatment, and as for insurance, well, I'll help out, we'll ask friends, family, I'll take up a collection at work, drunk people give money to anything-"

"No," said Lari, suddenly serious and calm, "no, this is it, I'm finally free. Don't you get it? No more school loans, no more credit card payments, nothing. I can do anything I damn well please, the worst that can happen is getting put in jail, but so what? Risking a few months in jail will be worth it."
11.title: Free

111.content:
After a few hours of trying to talk Lari out of committing grand larceny, Kat gave up. "Look, you can crash here tonight, but just for future reference, I don't harbor criminals and I don't aid and abet," she said.

In the morning, Lari started working on her plan. She went shopping, stopping at a gun store, a mask store, and the library. She needed information on the best way to go about robbing a bank. Sure enough, the library was a fountain of information. With that pesky "cooling off" period before buying a gun, she had plenty of time to research her plan. It would be nice to have co-conspirators, but she didn't know anyone she could trust, and she didn't exactly have ties to criminals.

In a few weeks, she decked herself out in a small arsenal of weopons. Knives, stun guns, mace, an AK-47 and a few pistols, all strapped to her body. She clothed herself in loose fitting clothes to hide her figure. Posing as a man would get her the most respect, and would be a great disguise.

Lari was set for her heist.
111.title: The heist

1111.content:
Lari decided to rob the bank on a Tuesday morning. It was Friday, leaving her a few days to practice her role as a man. She put the ski mask on over her head, and surveyed the world from the narrow slots allowed by the mask. She checked herself out in the bathroom mirror. Her pale blue eyes gazed back, revealing their femininity. Quickly, she found her sunglasses, and tried them on beneath the mask. It took her a few moments for her eyes to adjust to the light. Walking around the apartment, she decided she had to do something about her eyes. She could waste precious moments, not seeing clearly enough in the bank. She had to go to the mall anyway, to buy some baggy black pants and some shirts to bulk up and hide her slim figure.

Her first stop was the eyeglass store. They insisted on performing an eye exam before ordering colored contact lenses. The woman seemed confused when Lari told her she wanted dark brown contacts. "But you have such beautiful eyes," she said, "People ask us for contacts the color of those baby blues of yours."

"When will they be ready?" asked Lari.

"Well, your eye exam checked out, so the contacts will be ready for you Monday morning."

Her next stop was an inexpensive hair stylist. She asked for a pixie hair cut, and had her ash blonde hair dyed dark brown. Finally, she went to a used clothing store, where she found gloves, a few shirts, and the baggy black pants she was looking for. As she got out of the car at her apartment, she heard saw someone running up to her. It was Kat.

"Lari, I've been looking all over for you. Look, I took up a collection at work last night, and we made you $300 dollars. Please, just go to the doctor," she pleaded.

"It's too late, Kat, I've made up my mind. Want to hear my plan?"

--------
"So you're just going to waltz into a bank Tuesday morning, weilding a gun, posing as a man, in a ski mask, and you really think they're going to just hand over a million dollars?"

"Sure."

"By yourself."

"Sure."

"It will never work. You need backup. Haven't you ever seen Bonnie and Clyde?"

"Yeah, they went down in a hail of bullets. Beats dying in a sterile hospital bed."

"You really think so, don't you?" asked Kat. Lari nodded solemnly. "You've thought about this?" Again, Lari nodded. "I'd never forgive myself if you went down in a hail of bullets, kiddo. So what bank were you thinking about?"
1111.title: Co-Conspirator

11111.content:
"First of all," said Kat, "robbing a bank can be fairly easy. Most cops don't even bother trying that hard to find bank robbers, especially if you only do it once or twice. The stolen money is insured anyway, so the bank can afford a few robberies. Here's what we're going to do. I'll go in first, ask for change, ask a few other questions, distract the other teller long enough for you to do the actual robbing. I can also keep an eye out for cops and other suspicious behavior."

Lari looked excited. "Let's do it tomorrow, Kat!"

"Ok, tomorrow morning, at that same bank you've been scoping out. What times of the day are they slow for business?"

"Well, they open at 8:00. They get a little rush of people stopping in before work, and then between 9:30 and 10:00 they are pretty slow."

"9:30 it is," said Kat.

The next morning found them at the bank. Kat entered the bank wearing a tight red dress and a wide brimmed straw hat. She kept her head tilted down to minimize the amount of her face the wall mounted cameras could catch. There were two tellers on duty -one young, blonde, stylishly dressed female, and one older male, probably the manager on duty. There was only one customer in the bank, an older woman filling out a deposit slip. Kat went directly to the male teller, flashing him her brightest smile.

"Good morning! Pretty slow in here today, I know how boring that can be, I used to work at a really slow flower shop, the kind of place where you just pray for customers to walk in just to give you something to do!"

A moment later, Lari walked in. After deciding she wouldn't actually be able to pull of looking like a genuine boy, she would at least be able to dress like a bull dyke. She had found a black wig, and put a baseball cap on over it, and baggy pants with a tight white tank top and no bra. The old woman looked ready to approach the female teller. Lari quickly but casually cut the woman off and put her bag on the counter. She put her hand in the bag and left it there. With her other hand, she slipped a note to the teller. It said:

Hello, this is a robbery. Stay calm. Put all the money in your register into the paper sack you are about to be given.

The girl looked at Lari calmly. "Are you serious?"

"If I have to take the gun out of this bag, I'm going to shoot your fucking head off, bitch," said Lari in her deepest voice. She handed the girl the paper bag. Looking over at Kat, she could see the male bank teller looked transfixed. The female bank teller was looking that way, too, hesitating about what to do.

"Keep your eyes down," said Lari, "you have 30 seconds before I lose my fucking temper." Agitated, she moved her hand in the bag, as though she really wanted to pull the gun out. Slowly, the teller stared pulling money from the register. A stack of ones first, then the fives, then the tens, then the twenties, fifties, and finally the hundreds. Not too much, maybe a couple thousand, enough to get them out of town. The teller slid the paper sack across the counter. Lari grabbed it and stuffed it in her bag. She turned and walked out.

Kat giggled loudly and said, "Well, this has been fun, I'll think about that savings plan, in the meantime, I do have to get to work!" Lari was waiting in the car outside the bank. They sped off.
11111.title: Robbery

1112.content:
On the night when the moon was full, Lari robbed the bank. She crept toward the wall and had her back against it, peeping cautiously at the bank to monitor its current situation. After all, that's what the book said.

There was an old security guard pacing back and forth the main entrance of the bank. Lari searched her knapsack and took the wood and set it on fire, then, throwing it away from the bank. There, as easy as pie. The security guard chased the moving objects, frantically trying to put out the flames. Just as the book had predicted.

Lari knelt and crawled towards the main entrance. As she reached, her handphone rang loudly, grabbing the security guard's attention. The security guard had the flames melted down by then. He swerved around and squinted, trying to spot Lari in her black suit against the poorly lit entrance.

"Stop whoever you are!" the guard warned. His voice sounded weak. His movements were slow as he approached towards the camouflaged figure.

Well, Lari thought, smiling. I don't think he is a problem to me at all. She waited patiently for the guard to come. Lari was just right at his footstep ...
1112.title: Failure

She got medical attention and reported
11121.content:
Lari was just right at his footsteps when her handphone rang loudly. Oh, curses! She had forgotten turn off the phone.

"Ah, there you are!" said the old guard. He bent to grab Lari but Lari was quick and her night vision was better. She avoided his hands and kicked his leg. The old guard fell over, face first, groaning in pain.

Lari stood over the guard in triumph when she suddenly felt a piercing pain in her head. Her body grew weak and she shut her eyes, raising her hands against her temples. She opened her eyes again and saw that her vision was blurry.

The security guard was standing up by then and he was shouting. However, Lari couldn't hear what he said. The last thing she ever saw was a blurry figure trying to hold her.

112.content:
"Kat, we should take a trip," said Lari. I hate this town, we both do. No, don't interrupt me. Getting chemotherapy could kill me, surgery could kill me, but there's about a million things that I've never done, and I won't get a chance to do them if I don't do them right now."

"You're delirious," said Kat, "and I'm your best friend. I'll do whatever you want me to do, but I'm telling you this right now, I will never stop begging you to get treatment."

Lari laughed. "That's fine with me! Come on, when was the last time you saw mountains? Have you ever seen a glacier? A grizzly bear? A redwood tree? A volcano? Me neither!" She grabbed Kat's hands and started twirling her around madly. "Let's pack, let's go right this minute!"
112.title: Give me life or give me death

1121.content:
Kat had an old army jeep that she loved more than anything. As they headed on to the road, they drove through as many small towns as they could, just for the sake of taking a break from all the hustle in Lari's life. The engine chuckled once in a while as it entered the pit-holes on the roads but roared off as soon as Kat stepped and jammed hard on the accelerator.

All of a sudden the whole engine stopped in the middle of a dirt road. Kat tried to start the engine.Once. Twice.With no avail.

"Shit ! Fuck this jeep! Where the hell are we anyway?"

Lari looked at Kat, "You mean you have no idea where the hell we are? After all the traveling?"

"Honestly, no. I just drove but I didn't know where we were heading."

"NO SHIT ! you..you...oh god! " she swung her arms into the air to surrender. She wasn't really upset, after all, they both longed for adventure. Lari looked around. All she could see were some fields with cattle and sheep and far off was a small cottage with some smoke coming out of it. Lari thought miserably to herself: "First i'm diagnosed with a brain tumour, and now this. Some piece of shit."
1121.title: trouble

11211.content:
"Let's take stock," said Lari. "Ok, our jeep is broken down on a dirt road in NoWheresVille Missouri, there's a small hick house over yonder, we're young women, and it's getting dark. We're screwed."

"Well you've got nothing to lose, you're dying anyway. Shit we're all dying, the only difference is HOW we all die. I don't really feel like getting raped and murdered by a bunch of hillbillies, so if comes to that, I'll probably jam this pocket knife into my heart. But, they might not be hillbillies. Let's take a gamble, and see what happens."

"Right Kat," said Lari. They both sat in the jeep for a moment in silence, staring at the house in the distance. Taking a deep breath, Lari said, "Remember I love you."

As they walked up to the house, they could hear sounds of loud music and the occassional loud laugh from the woods behind the house.

"Sounds like they're having a party," said Lari as she knocked on the front door. Just then...
11211.title: nothing to lose

It seemed like forever before there was a response. the sound of some thrashing around and some voices. Lari made out one voice saying, " I think there's somebody here," the volume of the heavy metal music from within the house lowered and Lari shuddered as she heard footsteps approach the door.
When the door opened she felt a bit less threatened. I man that looked to be in his early thirties stood in the door. Tall and handsome, The man wore a t-shirt and jeans. He looked a bit suprised to see Lari and Kat at his front door.
"Who the hell is it Ozzie?" Lari heard a voice from within ask.
Lari was frozen with fear but Kat responded quickly, "My jeep broke down on the road nearby would you mind if we borrow your phone,"
"Sure" was all the man said stepping aside so they could walk in Kat immediatly entered. Lari hesitated and if it weren't for Kat dragging her by the arm she probably wouldn't have moved at all.
The dim light from inside the house hurt Lari's eyes as they adjusted. The guy who opened the door pointed to the phone setting on a table in the large undecorated room they had entered. There were five guys lounging around on old dilabidated furniture. Beer cans littered the room. Lari must have looked scared because the guy who opened the door said, "Don't worry about those bozo's they're harmless.

"Oh, for crying out loud, if he hasn't answered now, he's not going too."
"I'll try my dad, he never goes out," Kat said determinedly.

Kat was still calling anyone she could think of to no avail.

112112.content:
Lari hears a loud commotion from inside as you knock on the door. The music is cut suddenly, and people inside are yelling. They hear someone yell, "It's the fuzz!"

"They think we're cops!" says Kat. She reaches for the door and opens it.

Inside the house is mass chaos. People are passed out in corners, and beer bottles and marijuana bongs are strewn everywhere.

"We're not cops!" yells Lari, "Our car broke down-"

Suddenly a man grabs her around the neck and she feels the sharp point of a knife at her throat. "What the hell are you doing here?" he growls.

"Like I was trying to say, our car broke down-"

"It just happened to break down on county road 12, huh? Well, why don't you take me out to that car, and we'll see what's in the car."

Still holding her around the neck, the man, (she saw that another man was holding Kat in the same manner) marched them out of the house and down the road. Lari tried to speak to him.

"We don't have any weapons - you can check! Wouldn't cops have guns and stuff?

"Shut up."

"It's not very neighborly of you to not help someone with a broken down car. We just wanted to use your phone, and then we would have left!"

"Shut up."

"It looked like a fun party, I love Metallica as much as the next person! We could have partied with you!"

"You're a smart ass, you know that?" he said finally, "You got a death wish?"

They had arrived at the jeep. The man holding Lari told the other man to "grab her and don't let go." He held her around the wrist tightly while the other man searched the jeep with a flashlight.

"See? Nothing," said Lari. "Now are you going to help us or what?"
112112.title: Very bad men

1122.content:
Suddenly, a blinding white pain seered through Lari's head. She dropped to the ground, crying. Kat rushed to her side and held her, whispering soothing words. "It'll be alright, Lari, I'll get some aspirin, hold on."

She went to the sink and poured a glass of water, and grabbed the bottle of ibuprofin from the cabinet. Lari was still crumpled into a little ball on the floor, holding her head in her hands. When Kat approached, she snatched the ibuprofin out of her hands. Lari wrenched the top off, dumped the tablets onto the floor, and picked up a handful. She swallowed them, drinking thirstily from the glass of water. She continued rocking on the floor for awhile, until the migraine eased.

"It's still there, like a throbbing thing in my head," she explained quietly, "but I think I can move now. Hey, do you want to see if George wants to come with us?"

"He won't go for it," said Kat, "He's got a day job."

"He's also got a bitchin' new Jeep."

Kat's forehead furrowed. "Let's wait until he comes home. You look tired. Why don't you go lay down? I'll make you some tea."

George was a tall, lanky computer technician with an affinity for the outdoors. He worked in a downtown office building to make money, but longed to spend all of his spare time in the woods. He loved Kat, and thought of Lari as a little sister. They often spent entire weekends together, hiking, camping, and canoeing.

When he got home, he saw Kat sitting quietly at the dining room table, contemplating an empty bottle of beer. The apartment was silent, no lights were turned on. "What's wrong?" he asked immediately.

She pushed some papers toward him. "It's Lari. Remember all those migraines she's been having?"

"Yes..." he said, picking up the lab results and x-rays. "Heightened levels of white blood cells," he murmured, "tumor... in the brain."

He sat down heavily. "She's sleeping in the bedroom. I made her some tea with valerian. Makes you sleepy," Kat explained.

"Well, alot can be done with brain cancer now," said George, "It's definitely a survivable disease, though she might have to get brain surgery. But she's got us..." he trailed off as Kat shook her head.

"She doesn't want to treat it. She doesn't have health insurance, she's got nothing. I offered to take up a collection at the bar, but she's adament. She keeps talking about her last chance to really live. She wants to drive away."
1122.title: George comes home

11221.content:
George and Kat talked to Lari late into the night. They finally convinced her into going to the clinic to seek treatment. A few months later, after vigorously raising money for the operation, Lari had the tumor removed and was completely cured within the year.

She married a man she met in a brain cancer support group. He was loving, but overall rather mediocre. They bought a house, then a dog, and in no time at all, they had three children. Lari died at the ripe old age of 82, in her sleep. But she always had the most amazing dreams, most of which she wished she could have lived.
11221.title: A cure.

choices: Kat drags Lari to another doctor
11222.content:
Lari started to emerge from her light sleep, with the white light of pain easing to the back of her head as she looked at the ceiling fan. Round and round. The fan had no choices. The fan did what it was made to do. She had choices.

Lari could hear Kat and her boyfriend discussing her life, what she should do with what remained. A peace fell like a blanket around her as she realized that she was not alone in this, she would have someone to help her in her struggle. But her struggle would not be spent throwing up in metal tins as her hair fell out in clumps into her own vomit. No, she had a choice. And her choice was to live on her own terms and to feel like she made a dent in this world with her small existence.

She closed her eyes again and focused on the pain, pinpointing exactly where it was coming from. And Lari welcomed it. The tumor was hers and hers alone; too deep to be cut out, too big to risk killing off her soul with chemo-- but it had enough presence to make her change her life. And maybe someone else's.

"You see," she said, her blue eyes shining with pain and excitement, "This is how I would sum up my life: my whole life has been like laying in a hospital waiting room. Waiting for someone else to tell me how to live my life. Waiting for the inevitable diagnosis that will change everything. And now it has. And now I have to choose between fixing my brain, or fixing my life."

Kat didn't understand the excitement in her friend's eyes. She saw that her friend was giving up, and, dammit, she didn't want to watch her die.

"There's got to be something you can do!" she yelled.

Suddenly, George groaned. "Oh, Christ, Lari, did you even get a second opinion?"
11222.title: A Revelation

112221.content:
Stunned, Lari stared at George for a few breathless moments.

Finally she stammered, "Well, n-no, but, well, how could someone make a diagnosis like that if it wasn't true?"

"It happens all the time," said George, sweeping up the x-rays and doctor's papers, "I'm not a doctor, but I know one. Let's go."

Grabbing the shocked Lari by the arm, Kat followed George from the apartment out to the Jeep. They sped to a nearby hospital in grim silence, each wrapped up their own thougths. Kat vowed to wring the scrawny neck of the original doctor if this brain tumor diagnosis proved to be false. George tried to think about what other diseases could be mistaken for a brain tumor, but since he was just a computer technician, he could only think that maybe she was spending too much time in front of the computer, or maybe it was allergies. Lari made a vow with God, or Buddha, or Vishnu, or Allah, or whoever was listening, that if the diagnosis was false, she would change her life. She would devote her life to helping children, or animals, or the elderly, or the poor.

When they finally pulled up at the hospital, they rushed out of the Jeep and fled to the front desk.

"Can you please page Dr. Phillips?" gasped George to the astonished receptionist, "It's an emergency."

In a few minutes, a small, round doctor in a white coat, with a jelly doughnut in his hand, calmly turned a corner and walked up to them. Swallowing a bite of doughnut, he broke into smile when he saw George.

"Hey, cousin George," he said, "How's your mom and dad?"

"They're fine, Fred, but my friend here isn't so good. This is Lari."

Dr. Phillips smiled warmly at Lari, and said quietly, "What's the matter, Lari?"

Without saying a word, Lari handed him her medical file. Stuffing the rest of the doughnut in his mouth, he took the file and walked over to the receptionist's counter. He laid out the papers methodically, and began to read each one. He held up the x-rays to the light. After a few minutes, he grunted.

"Come here," he said gravely, "Let me show you something."
112221.title: The Second Opinion

12.content:
Lari didn't remember the drive home. She had vague recollections of driving too fast and honking. Now she was busily boxing up her stuff in the northeast Minneapolis apartment she rented by herself. She worked fervently, knowing that if she stopped for one moment, she would reconsider her options. Right now, she knew that what she really wanted was to dump the apartment, sell the stuff that was worth anything and store the rest at a mini storage.

She worked all night. There wasn't that much. She had three piles:
the stuff to sell: her bike, her futon, her TV/VCR/CD player, about a hundred CDs she wouldn't take with her, a microwave
Storage: Her books, personal items like worthless jewelry and semi-family heirlooms, a few shelves and small tables.
Stuff to take with: a backpack and a suitcase.

At 6:00 the next morning, she ran out to rent a U-Haul. She loaded the truck with her stuff to store first. When this was done, she sent the key with a letter to her mother. Pawning her stuff took a little longer. She only made about $500.00 on her stuff, but the pawnshop guy paid an additional $3,000.00 cash for her 3-year-old Honda Civic. If she hadn't been in a hurry, she could have gotten $10,000 for it. But she took the money gratefully.

By 7:00 that evening, she was finally exhausted. She slept on some clothes in her apartment, and woke at dawn the next day. She slipped a note under her landlord's door, and took a taxi to the airport.

"So where can I take you today," asked the slimy looking cabbie, eyeing her in the rearview mirror.

"Iceland," said Larie.
12.title: Clearing Out

121.content:
Lari loved airports. She loved the heightened sense of anticipation, the drama of saying goodbye, and being welcomed home. She eagerly watched the show, and drank her second beer. The plane to New York wouldn't depart for another two hours, and then she would have to wait six hours at LaGuardia. Plenty of time to get souced.

At the table to her right, an old man sat alone eating a pot roast with vegetables. Lari leaned over and said, "That looks good, how is the food here?"

He looked at her slowly. "The food is good, but the beer is better." Then he did something that surprised Lari. He reached into his bag, and took out a small white envelope. He set it on the table, looked at her meaningfully, and went back to eating his potroast.

Lari eyed it a moment, then motioned to the waiter. "I'll have what he's having," she said. While she was starting her dinner, the old man finished his. He looked at her strangely as he gathered his things together, then he picked up the envelope. He started to put it in his bag, but then fumbled with it and dropped it near her chair. He whispered, "Look, kid, take the envelope and give it to Jacques. He'll find you on the plane. Don't forget to wear the red hat."

Suddenly, they were both distracted by a commotion in the kitchen. There was a loud clattering of dishes, and a young Mexican dishwasher ran out the swinging doors, followed by a fat red-faced chef. "Out, out!" yelled the chef, throwing a towel at the young dishwasher. Lari laughed and looked back at the old man. He was gone, but the envelope was sticking out of her bag. Standing, she looked around for him, but the airport was swarming with busy travelers.

She sat down, suddenly self-conscious. "I feel like I'm in a spy novel. This is so surreal," she thought to herself. However, she finished her meal, not quite sure what to do with the envelope. But when she finished her food, she discovered it was almost time to catch her plane. On the way down the terminal, she spotted a shop selling sports momentos, including a rack of red baseball caps. For some reason, she found herself in the store, trying one on, and then purchasing it. Lari walked out of the store wearing the red cap, smiling to herself. "As if Jacques was going to be on the 2:15 plane to LaGuardia."

As she settled into the window seat, a hansome man sat down in the seat next to her, smiling. He held out his hand and said, "Hello, my name is Jacques."
121.title: A Mysterious Meeting

choices: The woman in the red hat
1211.content:
Jacques had the most beautiful eyes Lari had ever seen in a man. They were a deep chocolate brown, liquid, dark, and mysterious. She found herself staring into them, almost transfixed. "Are you French?" she blurted out, and then wanted to kick herself for being so unsmooth. "-I mean, what a great accent you have."

The Frenchman smiled softly, and continued to gaze at her. "I thought you were dead," he said, suddenly whispering, and looking around furtively. "My contact told me this morning that the woman in the red cap had probably been eliminated during her last job. Explain yourself," he demanded.

Lari's mind raced. This WAS a spy novel, and she was caught in the middle. Then, the reality of her imminent death crashed over her, and she thought up a doozy of a lie.

"I was ambushed, but they did a sloppy job of it. I wounded two of those dogs and killed another. A woman. I put my hat on her ugly head and left her there. My plan worked. I'm surprised you decided to follow through on this."

"This is the highest priority, madame, I had to take the chance that the envelope would find it's way to me by other means. May I have it now?"

She reached into her bag, and drew out the thick envelope. Regretfully, she handed it to Jacques. "Why do you trust me?" she asked.

"You've got to trust someone in this work," he said, "besides, my contact said the woman in the red hat was a beautiful red-head, with stunning blue eyes."

Soon, the plane was taking off. As it veered east, Lari and Jacques found they had a lot in common, though it seemed an unspoken agreement that they would not talk about their work. Too risky. As they stood in the terminal in New York, Jacques put Lari's hand to his lips, and kissed it softly.

"We will meet again someday," he said, "your blue eyes and copper hair will stay in my memory always."
1211.title: Lies

12112.content:
Lari decided to get a make-over. She had never been that interested in her looks, but what the hell? She didn't have anything to lose, and the adventure on the plane made her want to turn into someone else.

"Do whatever you need to do to make me look fabulous," she told the hairdresser. Her copper hair was cut short, and blonde highlights were added to give it a modern look. During her manicure, Lari noticed a woman under a hair dryer, peering at her from behind a newspaper. The woman quickly hid her face when her eyes met Lari's. She didn't see the woman in the salon again because she was whisked away to get her face made over.

After the salon, Lari decided to get some new clothes. Again, she saw a woman watching her from the other end of the store. The woman left hurriedly when Lari approached.

Newly armed with a stunning leather outfit, but feeling like a super-spy poseur, Lari started up the escalator to catch her flight to Iceland. Suddenly, someone caught her elbow roughly and a harsh female voice whishpered in her ear, "Don't turn around, look straight ahead. You've really gotten me in trouble now, girl."

Out of the corner of her eye, Lari caught a glimpse of bright curly red hair poking boldly out from beneath the brim of a red hat.
12112.title: Super Spy

121121.content:
The woman in the red hat steered Lari into a phone booth and shut the door. Lari got a good look at her. She was an older woman, late thirties, but still very attractive. She had big curly red hair, and a stylish wide brimmed red hat.

"So, explain yourself," said the woman, "Why do you go around impersonating me?"

Lari decided to drop the charade and spill everything. "It was a mistake," she admitted, "I asked some old guy in a restaurant how his dinner was, and he gave me this envelope. He told me to wear a red hat, give the envelope to a guy named Jacques, and then he disappeared. I just decided to go along for the hell of it."

The red-haired woman looked at her closely and said, "You got me into a lot of trouble. I faked my death so I could, well, nevermind, but you better not pose as me anymore. It could prove deadly for you. I've made myself a few enemies with this little stunt. As if I needed more enemies. Look, just lay off wearing any red hats from now on, and as far as your concerned, you don't know me, you don't know Jacques, and this incident never happened. Now, where are you traveling to?"

"Iceland."

"Good, stay out of the country for awhile. Here's a tip though... don't go to England or France. Don't ask why, just don't go. Got it?"

"Yes," said Lari hesitantly, "But, come on, what was in the envelope?"

"Forget it, kid, go have a wonderful time in Iceland and have a great life. Hopefully this little mistake won't haunt you forever."

She opened the door and disappeared into the crowded airport. Lari looked at her watch and then grabbed her bags and ran to the gate. She was one of the last people on the flight. She sank into her seat gratefully, thinking about the wonderful hot mineral springs of Iceland.

Suddenly, she felt someone tugging her sleeve. She looked up and saw...
121121.title: Lectured

1211212.content:
the flight attendent who leaned over her, smiling, and tugging gently at her sleeve.

"Miss," the tall blonde said softly, "we are preparing to land at Reykjavik. Would you please fasten your seatbelt?”

Lara straightened up in her chair as the flight attendant moved towards the next passenger. She realized suddenly that she had been sleeping for several hours. She felt much better since the fatigue that had gripped her when she boarded had now departed. She fastened the seatbelt around her slender waist, tugging it tight with the strap. She ran her fingers through her tousled red hair and leaned over to look out the airplane window.

Below was startling beauty of rugged land, mountains, a river, and the city or Reykjavik below her, small and friendly looking. Steam and fog pulsed out of the crevasses in the mountains from the many volcanoes she knew dwelt there. She remembered reading tales of ancient dragons that lived in these vast stretches of wilderness.

She would have liked to go to the restroom and wash her face, but that was out of the question now that the plane was beginning it’s descent towards the small airport. A few minutes later, she stepped down the gangplank, enjoying the cool air, and looking around at the hills and mountains that surrounded the city.

As she walked through the gate, her jaw dropped at what she saw.
1211212.title: Iceland At Last

121122.content:
"Ok, so who are you?" Lari said, feeling the normal sense of danger, but standing her ground, and holding her head high.
"My name is of no importance to you and the mission you have just been granted" said the copper curled stranger as she surveyed the people rushing by with caution. "What you did took guts my girl. And for it you should be punished. We have decided although, to take you on board. You will now take my position as the alliance. Go now. The hotel across the street has a reservation for Allions. You are now Dr Chase Allions. You will live and breathe by that name until I tell you otherwise. Go now! Oh. A package will be delivered to you at precicley 10pm. It will contain clothes, passports and many other things." the woman said looking with scorn at Lari's freshly bought clothes.
"but what is wrong with my....." Lari began, but the woman had gone.

1211221.content:
Lari felt the adrenalin rush like she had never felt before. She debated in her mind about walking out of this spy novel and getting back to her remaining 6 months (or 5 months and 29 days) of her life. She could become a recluse for those remaining days and be burried in a nameless grave; or she could go in a blaze of glory.

The blaze sounded better.

Lari reached the hotel and checked in as Dr. Chase Allions. She waited with baited breath as the time approached 10:00 pm. When she heard the knock on the door, she pretended to check her non-existing gun in her holster, and carefully opened the door.

“Dr. Allions?” The man in the grey suit inquired standing outside the door. A blue carry on bag with British Airways logo on it sat on the floor by his feet.
“Yes?” She said, trying to keep the shiver of excitement out of her voice.
“I have a delivery for you” He lifted the carry on and handed it to her.
She nodded as if she knew all about it…and thanked him and took the bag inside. Her heart raced as she placed the bag on the bed and opened it to check the contents.
The bag was very well arranged….the flap on the top held a passport and three envelopes. A quick shuffle through the bulk of the contents made her blush slightly. There was a skimpy lingerie, a couple of thongs and the type of undewear which she had never worn in her life. The other side of the bag held hand written scientific journals. The first journal caught her attention. It read: “Doctorate thesis in terahertz study of transient excitons for stealth lasers” by Dr. Chase Allions. She flipped through the pages and saw nothing but a million formulae, technical diagrams, graphs and scientific mumbo jumbo that was way beyond her comprehension.

There was a voice recorder with a micor-tape in it. She pressed the play button and started listening…..
1211221.title: The Package

1212.content:
"Hello Jacques, my name is Lari," she said.

He sat down next to her. "That is not the correct reply," he said casually. "Where is the envelope? You are clearly not the person Heinrich thought you were."

"No," said Lari, "I don't think I am. I just asked this old man how his dinner was, and he told me to wear a red hat and take this envelope. I almost chucked it."

He looked alarmed, "You didn't!"

"No," she said, pulling it out of her bag, "if it's that important, I don't want it. I don't have enough time left to worry about some apparant espionage." She laughed carelessly. As if she were a spy!

Jacques grabbed the envelope greedily. He felt it carefully. Sighing deeply, he put the envelope into his own bag. "Now, let me buy a beautiful, mysterious woman, a drink."

They spent the rest of the flight flirting and drinking heavily. It was a long flight. Eventually, Lari fell asleep on Jacques' shoulder. When she woke up, she looked out the window at the endless expanse of sky, just turning a dark somber violet in the twilight. Smiling, she turned to Jacques. He seemed to still be sleeping. She shook him gently. He slumped against her, a dead weight impossible to move. Alarmed, she shook him roughly, slapping his face. Her hand went to his neck, searching for a pulse. It was what she feared - he was dead.
1212.title: A Turn of Events

choices: He forgot to take his meds
12121.content:
Lari stood up unsteadily, without thinking. She scanned the plane for a stewerdess. Not seeing one, she made her way to the back of the plane. Peering behind a curtain, she saw two stewerdesses speaking together closely. Lari walked in on weak legs and said, "You aren't going to believe this, but the person sitting next to me is dead!"

The stewerdesses both jumped into action "I'll tell the captain," said one, "I'll check this out," said the other. The first rushed to the cockpit, while the second stewerdess said, "You look terrible. Do you want a drink of water?"

Lari nodded and accepted the water gratefully. Slowly, her wits were coming back to her, and she realized she could now be in some trouble. She might even be questioned by the police. The envelope! What was in it? Who would want it? Was Jacques murdered? If so, the murderer was on the plane. If not, it was a hell of a coincidence.
12121.title: Shocked

121212.content:
"Feeling better?" asked the stewerdess, a striking woman with a Brooklyn accent. "You've got some color in your face at least. Now, you do have to show me where you are sitting, but we have to be as discreet as possible so as not to frighten the other passengers."

"Of course," said Lari, trying not to sound nervous. "My name is Lari, by the way."

"Jeanette. We should hurry, the captain is going to announce our arrival in about 5 minutes."

Jeanette followed to where Jacques was still lying, slightly tipped toward the window. She bent over him to obscure him from the other passengers and put her fingers to his throat. Lari surveyed the cabin, where most people were either sleeping or staring out the window. Jeanette stood up and gently took Lari's elbow, guiding her to the front of the plane. "Well, we have a problem, honey. He's as dead as a doornail, but we don't have any other seats available. Would you feel terribly uncomfortable sitting beside him until we land? It won't be long."

Just then the co-pilot stepped out of the nearby cockpit. "Do we have a situation, Jeanette?" he asked.

"Yes, he doesn't have a pulse. None of the passengers have been alerted or seem to be aware. But we don't have any other seats available for Lari, who was sitting beside him."

"Were you traveling together," he asked.

"No, we just met. We talked a bit, but then we both fell asleep."

"And how do you feel about returning to your seat?"

Lari hesitated. If she went back to her seat, she could check and see if the envelope were still with him. On the other hand, she'd be sitting next to a corpse. Not an attractive option.
121212.title: The Corpse

1212121.content:
"I don't want to make a fuss," said Lari, "I'll just pretend he's still sleeping."

The co-pilot took her hand and said, "I'm very sorry this happened. I appreciate your help in this matter. When we land, Jeanette here will make sure you are one of the first people off the plane. You will probably have to make a statement to the police, though."

"I understand," she said.

As they walked back to the seat, the pilot's voice was heard saying, "We will be landing in a few minutes. Please put on you lapbelts and turn off all cell phones and electronic equipment. Welcome to New York." Lari eased into her window seat, trying not to touch Jacques as much as possible. It was dark outside, but the earth was covered in lights. Lari wanted to watch the landing, but her curiosity got the better of her. She reached gingerly for the bag under his seat. She slid it out carefully, trying not to move his legs. She got the bag out just far enough to unzipper it. The envelope was still there! He hadn't been murdered!

Relieved, she turned back to the window. Then she had an interesting thought. What if she took the envelope? She would have plenty of opportunity to inspect its contents at LaGuardia. But maybe she should just leave all this behind, and concentrate on relaxing and enjoying her trip. She was really looking forward to those hotsprings in Iceland, and after Iceland she planned on visiting Sweden to trace her roots. It had always been her dream to know where her grandparents came from.
1212121.title: Curiosity

122.content:
They'd been in the air for three hours when it happened. Lari was listening to the radio through the thin head phones, trying to figure out why she'd chosen Iceland of all places. She heard a crash and opened her eyes to see four people dressed in black, all holding guns. The plane was being hijacked!
Lari should have felt frightened, but instead excitement stirred in her chest. Her heart was pounding and her blood was flowing. She felt more alive than she had in years.

One the the men with guns walks over to her...his dark blue eyes peirced her being. Lari set her jaw, ready to take the bullet for the child she hardly knew, but the man just passed her with a grunt. Lari felt a sense of Victory she had held her ground..anything she wanted she could take. Unless it was...

12212.content:
Surreptitiously, Lari evaluated the hijackers. They were all men, white, of various ages, heights, and hair colors. The man with the striking blue eyes was the youngest, in his early twenties. Another one was older, maybe about 30 and had blond hair, but Lari determined that it was a color job, and that he probably had quite dark hair, as his eyebrows were very dark and he had somewhat of a Mediterranian look about him. The other two were in their 30s, and stood very calmly in the aisle keeping an eye on the passengers and on the cock pit door. They both had dark hair and were quite pale. Lari thought they both looked like computer programmers, with their thin intelligent faces, and lack of exposure to the sun. She also thought they might be brothers. All four men wore black from head to foot; black t-shirts, black pants, and black combat boots. She could only assume that at least two other men had stormed the cockpit already, although she did not feel any changes in the way the plane was flying - no sudden shift in altitude or direction.

The other passengers all looked terrified. It was not a huge plane, the flight was not full, and thus there were only about 30 people on board, and they were spread out, many people had rows of seats to themselves. It was easy for the high jackers to ensure that nobody spoke to anybody.

Suddenly, there was a commotion at the back of the plane as the flight crew all emerged from the rear compartment, hands raised, the high jacker with the blue eyes motioning them forward with a very menacing looking gun.

"I wonder how they got those guns on board," whispered the woman next to Lari. "After 9-11..."

She was cut off by the loudspeaker crackling, and soon the pilot's voice was heard, "This is your captain speaking. Don't panic. We will be landing in Iceland shortly and you will be getting on with your lives. However, we will not be landing in Rekyavik, we will be landing in another city, one that is more friendly to our ... um ..." There was a thud, and his voice was cut off. A voice with a German accent said, "We are not suicide bombers, so you do not have to fear for your lives. There is simply a matter of some cargo on board that rightfully belongs to us. Now everyone, please cooperate. Put your head down between your legs, don't speak, and we will arrive at our destination in a little less than an hour."
12212.title: The Hijackers

122121.content:
Staring at the floor of the plane as the hijackers instructed, Lari thought about what the German had just said over the intercom. Something about valuable cargo. Naturally, the only way to get planes on an airplane would be if the airport workers helped somehow. The people who load the plane, or the security workers themselves, would all have an easier time of getting weapons on board. Maybe they were paid off by the hijackers, or maybe they planted people in the airport months or years ago, just waiting for an assignment like this...

Lari's musings were interrupted by a tap on the shoulder. Looking up, she saw the piercing blue eyes of the good-looking hijacker. "Come with me," he said, not unkindly, motioning with his head towards the back of the plane. Not seeing any other choice, as he held a very large, very menacing gun, Lari stood up, wobbling slightly out of nervousness.

Once the door closed behind them, she smiled bravely at him and said, "It's good to stand again after sitting for four hours. I wish you'd let the other passengers stretch a little bit."

"Cut the shit," he sneered, leaning in close, "Who the hell are you? Traveling alone, good looking woman, nice suit, smart attitude... CIA? FBI? I should kill you now."

Lari suddenly realized that her six months to live could very well be quickly reduced to six seconds. "I'm not, not CIA or FBI or anything. I'm nothing. Just a smartass. My wallet is in my purse, under my seat. Go get it, you can look through all my stuff."

"Then what the fuck are you?"

"I'm a student, I write for a college newspaper, that's why I have the smart attitude. As for the traveling alone and the nice suit, well, I'd like to get an internship for a travel magazine, but I need to work on my portfolio. Iceland seemed like a unique place to write about."

While the lies tumbled from her mouth effortlessly and surprisingly sincerely, the blue eyed hijacker searched her face intently. Suddenly, he punched open the nearby door and one of the other hijackers entered. Blue Eyes said, "Go get J. Tell him to bring me whatever is under seat A, Row 13."

The burly hijacker left with a grunt. Blue Eyes moved closed to Lari, shouldering his gun by its strap. "Fold your hands behind your head," he said quietly, "I'm going to check you for listening or tracking devices. If you move, I'll snap your pretty little neck like a twig." Slowly, thoroughly, his hands began moving over her body, starting with her hair, behind her ears, moving down to her neck, shoulders, down her back to her legs, and then up again. All the time, his eyes gazed at her. Finally, he said, "Take off your shoes." After scrutinizing her black pumps and squeezing their insides, he handed them back to her. Just then, the burly hi jacker entered, gripping Lari's bag in his big glove.

"Keep your gun pointed at her," said Blue Eyes while he dumped the contents of Lari's bag on the floor. Kneeling down, he picked up her spiral bound journal and paged through. "That's personal," said Lari heatedly. The burly man with the gun grunted menacingly.

"I can see that," said Blue Eyes, "I'm going to peek at your last entry though. 'The plane is about to take off for Iceland. I hate flying, so I'm going to write about my fellow passengers. There is a woman sitting next to me with a little boy. I wonder where his father is...'

He trailed off and skimmed over the next few pages, then looked at Lari. "Well, it doesn't sound like something an agent would write." He carefully sorted through the other things in the bag, the make up bag, water bottle, granola bars, chocolate, headset and music tapes.

Then he said something unexpected.

Meeting his eyes, she said, "You have beautiful eyes, everyone on this plane will remember you and be able to identify you. What is really going on here?"

Grimacing, he said, "Are you looking for an interview?"

"If I get my notebook back, I could take some notes."

He laughed scornfully. "The American press doesn't want this story. People wouldn't believe you anyway. Go back to your seat, college girl and forget about me and this plane and everything that happened today. The rest of the world will."

He started to take her elbow and shove her towards the door, but she exclaimed, "Wait, wait! Seriously, a plane full of American citizens gets hi-jacked by an group of gun-wielding tough guys, and you think nobody is going to care? I care! Come on, this could really be my break, and I could help you out! You sound like you WANT the world to hear your story!"

Suddenly, Lari was living the life she always dreamed about. Always a prudent, serious person, she had majored in business administration in college and for the last two years had been stuck in a well-paying but dead end office job. Becoming a reporter had always seemed like a pipe dream.

He paused for a beat and then said abruptly, "Go back to your seat," and pushed her through the door. Disappointed, she stumbled back to her seat. The woman with the little boy looked at her searchingly, but didn't say anything. Lari mouthed the words "I'm OK" and smiled.

Suddenly the plane gave a jerk and everyone screamed. Lari looked out the window just as a fighter jet streaked past. Several gunmen ran to the cock-pit as the plane stabilized and a few moments passed. The passengers were now talking to one another freely, but then Blue Eyes and one of the pale dark haired men emerged from the cockpit. Dark Hair yelled "Shut uup!" and pointed his gun around the cabin. Blue Eyes, however, was looking right at Lari.

"You!" he yelled, "College girl! Up here, now!"

It looked like Lari was going to get a chance to live her dream after all.

13.content:
Lari slept. During her adventures on the freeway, she cut people off, changed lanes without using her blinker, randomly sped up and then slowed down suddenly, rode people's asses, screamed, and gave the finger to about 25 different individuals. She felt very tired. Acting like people she hated took a lot out of her.

When she woke up, she sat groggily looking out living room window at the dismal view of an alley. Nothing moved in the early evening light. "Everything looks beautiful in this light," she thought. She had hoped for a mystical dream that would tell her what to do and where to go, but that dream had not occurred. Her sleep had been deep and unsatisfying.

As her thoughts moved from the alley to her stomach, she decided that the experiment in being someone else had not made her feel better. She was not an asshole. She would not live the next six months pissing people off and eating nothing but doughnuts. Just because she would not seek treatment for her condition, did not mean she would change her whole personality. As she crunched some carrots, and perused her foodstocks, she thought about the things she most cared about. Music, art, reading, nature. Halfway through her college career, she had discovered the exquisite pleasure of sitting in a forest and listening to the awesome rush of wind in the leaves, or the equally awesome silence of a dark woods. Unable to concentrate on her business degree, she had dropped out of school and found work at a temp agency. That was a year ago. All her money went towards paying off her school debt, her car loan, rent, and escaping from the city on the weekends, and any other chance she got. She had few friends, and did not date. Her only companion was her cat, Demeter. Her non-nature time was spent reading about nature - birds, flowers, soil, grasses, forests, mountains, field guides, and nature magazines.

Waiting for her soup to boil, she thumbed through one of these magazines. There was a blurb near the back that she had somehow missed, and she read it now.

"Homes Destroyed by Eco-Terrorists"

Long Island, NY - Officials suspect a group of eco-terrorists known as Save the World for the destruction of three houses on Long Island. The uncompleted houses were part of a housing development that the group opposes. No people were harmed in the attack.

"I can't save myself, Demeter," she told her cat, scratching Demeter behind the ears. "But I'm not dead yet."

She walked over to her garbage can and dug into it, looking for junk mail. She spent the rest of the evening filling out applications for credit cards. She decided to give herself a month to make money at her job, not pay her bills, sell her stuff, get a collection of credit cards, sell her blood plasma, and get a night job. 131.title: Plans

1312.content:
Lari piled her car with everything she was keeping. Before heading out of town, she stopped to get a few supplies. She went to a drug store, and bought a men's hair cutting kit, several bottles of water, a tarp, and a few other things she would need for a cross country trip of a few days.

She drove. She chose west, with a vague idea of going to the mid size California town of El Oro, the supposed center of an environmental/anarchist group. This group had been involved in a number of demonstrations all along the Pacific Coast. Their spokesman, a soft spoken writer, lived in El Oro, and regularly met with anyone who had any interest in talking about the movement. Lari hoped to meet some of the members of this group, and devote the rest of her short life to bringing down the status quo, capitalist American machine.

After driving across the flat Midwestern farmland for several hours, Lari stopped at a rest area. She grabbed the hair cutting kit, and entered the ladies room. She looked thoughtfully at the scissors, and then proceeded to roughly cut her hair. When it was short enough, she got out the electric razor and shaved her head.

Just as she was cleaning the hair out of the sink, a young woman walked into the bathroom. The woman stopped short when she saw Lari. "Did you just shave your head in here?" she asked. Lari nodded. "Why?"

"I'm going to California. It's going to be hot there, and my hair will only get in the way."

"Oh. That's interesting. My name is Maude."

Lari wiped off the sink with a paper towel and didn't reply. She just wanted to get back on the road.

"Well good luck out there," said Maude. "California isn't all it's cracked up to be."
1312.title: Prepared

13121.content:
"Why do you say that?" asked Lari, "That California isn't all it's cracked up to be?"

Maude entered a stall, shut the door, and said, "I saw your license plate. Midwestern girl like you is probably looking for some adventure. Trust me, the dot coms have destroyed everything."

"It's technology," said Lari, "Why does everyone assume that progress has to mean growth? Growth in population, growth in technology, in jobs, and material goods? I wish I could stop it all."

Maude came out of the stall, looking at Lari peculiarly. She washed her hands, and then reached into her backpack. "Here, take this," she said, "It's my favorite book, I think I've read it so much I've memorized it."

Lari looked at the book. "The Monkey Wrench Gang," by Edward Abbey.

"It's got some great ideas in it," said Maude as she left the restroom.

The next morning, Lari called in sick...permanently. She slept late, and then put on a little dress to go get coffee.

As she was waiting at the counter for her latte, she noticed an attractive man trying to catch her eye at a nearby table. She smiled at him, and when her coffee was ready, she walked to his table and asked if he was waiting for anybody. When he said "no," she noticed he had the most beautiful...
